Application of plasma technology in the removal of volatile organic compounds (BTX) using manganese oxide nano-catalysts synthesized from spent batteries

a b s t r a c t
In this paper, the powder of manganese oxide was recovered from spent alkaline batteries and the effect of calcination temperature on the physiochemical properties of resultant powder was studied. Synthesized manganese oxide was impregnated at different percentages on alumina and the resultant material was used as catalyst for oxidation of benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) in a hybrid plasma-catalytic process. Manganese oxide/alumina (MnAl) catalysts were analyzed by FTIR, XRD, FESEM, EDX, BET, TEM, and TPR-H2 and the results indicated that high crystalline big cubes of manganese oxide are in good connection with highly dispersed ultra-fine nanoparticles of alumina. Enhancing the Mn content increased the agglomeration of alumina particles probably around the cubes of manganese oxide. Nitrogen adsorption measurements (BET) showed that the specific surface area of these catalysts was high but reduced with increasing Mn percent. TPR-H2 showed that using alumina had a good impact on the redox ability of the catalyst. Oxidation of BTX using synthesized MnAl catalysts was carried out in the presence of plasma. While MnAl catalysts showed similar results in benzene and toluene oxidation percent (97e98%), the oxidation of xylene was difficult and depended on the Mn percent so that the catalyst with 10% wt. of manganese oxide indicated 74% of xylene oxidation while higher or lower Mn contents exhibited lower oxidation percent. In order to evaluate the experimental parameters, the influence of plasma input voltage, catalyst location in the plasma reactor, BTX flow rate, and the catalyst loadings were investigated. Results showed that benzene and toluene were oxidized almost completely regardless of input plasma voltage but the amount of xylene oxidation soared with increasing the voltage. Moreover, the catalyst location in the reactor had no significant influence on the conversion of BTX whereas increasing the flow rate led to a decline in BTX removal efficiency.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays air pollution is one of themajor problems that human communities are facing with. Volatile organic compounds (VOCs), which are released from different sources like vehicles and stationary industries, are one of the main sources of air pollution. These compounds cause diverse diseases in humans, even cancer, and are also highly detrimental to the environment; Greenhouse
culty, Sahand University of Tabriz, Iran.
effect which leads to global warming is one of their outcomes (Li and Gaillard, 2009; Aguero et al., 2009). Therefore, it is necessary to control their emission and eliminate these compounds from air in the case of release. Numerous processes are using for removal of VOCs from air; adsorption, thermal oxidation and catalytic oxidation, photocatalysis, membrane separation and bioreaction (Khan and Ghoshal, 2000). The main problems of these processes are high costs and the hardness of operation especially in low concentrations of VOCs.
Lately, non-thermal plasma (NTP) has gained a lot of attention due to its high performance in degrading VOCs inmild condition. In NTP, VOC degradation happens through the interactions of VOC molecules with high energy electrons, excited oxygen and nitrogen
species and hydroxyl radicals. However, high energy consumption and production of some unwanted byproducts during the oxidation process are two main drawbacks of using this technology in an industrial scale. A combination of NTP and catalysis was used to solve the mentioned drawbacks. Introducing the catalysts can enhance the reaction rate, selectivity and energy consumption of the plasma (Delagrange et al., 2006; Schiavon et al., 2015, 2017a, 2017b; Nguyen et al., 2018; Van Durme et al., 2007).
Various metallic oxides were used as catalysts in the plasmacatalytic oxidation processes. Manganese oxide was used in numerous researches and showed promising results regarding VOC degradation due to its high activity and stability (Aguilera et al., 2011; Zhu et al., 2016; Santos et al., 2010; Kim and Shim, 2010; Wang et al., 2016, 2017; Baldi et al., 1998). Wang et al. evaluated the effect of different manganese precursors for manganese loaded Al2O3 catalysts and confirmed that introducing the catalysts into the process, improved the xylene removal, CO2 selectivity and COx yield (Wang et al., 2016). It is reported that active oxygen species, which are formed during the decomposition of O3, have an important role in VOC degradation. Manganese oxide catalyst is the most active catalyst in the decomposition of O3. This high activity is due to the existence of high efficient oxidation cycles, existence of lattice oxygen and different types of manganese ions like Mn4þ/Mn3þ and Mn3þ/Mn2þ (Bastos et al., 2009; Gandhe et al., 2007; Wang et al., 2007).
Manganese oxide can be found in alkaline and Zn/C batteries. In the last two decades, using these types of batteries soared due to their application in different electronics and their low cost. These batteries designed to be used once and should be thrown away after they died but they contain heavy metals which make them a very serious problem to the environment due to their toxicity for both air and water (Gomes et al., 2016). A large proportion of an alkaline battery is consisted of manganese oxide. Recovering and synthesizing materials from various kinds of waste is getting an enormous attention in recent years due to its effect on environment and potential of using the materials in different applications (Samaddar et al., 2018; Kim et al., 2018; Sun et al., 2016). Manganese can be recovered using metallurgical methods such as hydrometallurgy. In the hydrometallurgical process, diluted strong acids like H2SO4 is used for leaching components like Mn and Zn from battery powder according to the reactions below (De Michelis et al., 2007; Tanong et al., 2017; Sayilgan et al., 2009):
ZnOþH2SO4/ZnSO4 þ H2O (1)
MnOþH2SO4/MnSO4 þ H2O (2)
Mn2O3 þH2SO4/MnSO4 þMnO2 þ H2O (3)
Mn3O4 þ 2H2SO4/2MnSO4 þMnO2 þ 2H2O (4) In this paper, the possibility of using manganese oxide which recovered from spent battery powder as active phase in an alumina supported catalyst is evaluated. The characterization of manganese oxide/alumina (MnAl) catalysts were done by Fourier-transformed infrared (FTIR), X-ray diffraction (XRD), field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX), Nitrogen adsorption measurements (BET), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and temperature-programmed reduction (TPR-H2) analyses. The catalytic activity of the synthesized catalysts in the degrading of benzene, toluene and xylene (BTX) was investigated via both routs of thermal-catalytic oxidation and plasma-catalytic oxidation. The effect of calcination temperature, manganese oxide loading on alumina and different operational conditions in the removal efficiency was also evaluated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: In order to synthesize the catalysts, size D alkaline batteries were used. The sulphuric acid which was used in the hydrometallurgical process was purchased from DRM Company in Iran. Alumina as the support of catalyst was purchased from Iran Alumina Company and benzene, toluene, and xylene as pollutants were purchased from Merck and DRM companies.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nanocatalyst preparation and procedures
sections.text:
After dismantling the batteries, the powder inside the battery was separated and deionized water was used to wash the powder in order to separate the KOH. After three washing processes, the powder was filtrated. Then, the remained solid was placed in the oven at 110 C for 24 h. Afterwards, the dried powder was used in the leaching process with diluted H2SO4 (0.5% v/v) with solid/liquid ratio: 1/60 (gr/ml) at 70 C for 4 h. The remaining solid was filtered and washed with deionized water for several times after the leaching process and then dried at 110 C for 12 h. In the final step, the solid was calcined at four different temperatures; 400, 500, 600, and 700 C in order to evaluate the proper calcination temperature.
Finally, using the wet impregnation method, manganese oxide
Fig. 2. Plasma-catalyti
was deposited on alumina with different percentages (5, 10, and 15%). A solution of alumina and deionized water were mixed for half an hour and then manganese oxide was added to the solution. In the end, the catalyst was calcined at 600 C for 3 h. The procedure of catalyst synthesis is shown in Fig. 1.

sections.heading: 2.3. Nanocatalyst characterization techniques
sections.text:
Surface functional groups were identified using a Tensor 27 Fourier spectrometer made by Bruker which recorded FTIR in a range of 4000-400 cm 1. In order to evaluate the structural characteristics of the synthesized catalysts, X-ray diffraction (XRD) method was conducted using a Siemens diffractometer D500 with monochromatized Cu K a (k¼ 1.54178 Å). The rate of scanning was 0.02 /s radiation at 40 kV and 30mA. 2q range was from 10 to 90 . In order to identify the phases, Joint Committee on Powder Diffraction Standards (JCPDS) was used for comparison. Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) was used to investigate the morphology, microstructure, and particle size using a KYKY EM 320. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis was used to detect elements in catalysts by the same equipment. Using BET (Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller) method, N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms in 77 K were measured to gain specific surface area of the each catalyst using Quantachrome CHEMBET 3000. Further investigation of the morphology of the synthesized catalysts was conducted by transmittance electron microscopy (TEM) using a TECNAI G220 operated at 200 kV, with LaB6 electron emitter. H2-Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR) experiments was carried out using NanoSORD NS91 apparatus in order to evaluate the redox ability of the catalysts. sections.heading: 2.4. Experimental setup for catalytic performance test
sections.text:
The plasma-catalytic oxidation setup for BTX oxidation is shown in Fig. 2. In this setup, BTX streams were produced by using pure air passing through the saturators which were filled with benzene, toluene and xylene. In order to prevent any change in the inlet rate of pollutants to the air, all the saturators were placed in an ice bath. Another stream for pure air was also considered in order to regulate the concentration of pollutants. Thermal and plasma oxidation tests were conducted. In thermal tests, a U-shaped reactor made of Pyrex with an inner diameter of 6mm was used. In plasma tests, catalysts were placed in a vertical DBD reactor made of Pyrex. The length of the reactor was 150mmwith an inner diameter of 15mm. High voltage electrode was a steel rod placed on the axis of the reactor and the ground electrodewas an aluminium sheet wrapped on the outside of the reactor. Plasma was generated using a DC power supply in different voltages.
In order to deter pressure drop, catalysts were shaped in the form of 1mm pellets and for each test 0.2 gr of catalyst was placed in the reactor. In this paper both IPC (in plasma catalysis) and PPC (post plasma catalysis) tests were conducted. This was achieved by changing the position of the aluminium sheet on the DBD reactor.
Before each test, contaminated air passed through the catalysts for 20min in order to prevent adsorption of pollutants on the surface of the catalyst affects the removal efficiency of the catalyst.

sections.heading: 3.1. Effect of Manganese Oxide Calcination Temperature
3.1.1. FTIR analysis
sections.text:
The spectra of FTIR for pure manganese oxide catalysts which were calcined at four different temperatures (Mn400, Mn500, Mn600 and Mn700) are shown in Fig. 3. The number after the Mn refers to the calcination temperature of the catalyst. The peaks related to the metals are in the region below 1000 cm 1. The bands at 514, 526, and 760 cm 1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the MneO group in the catalyst (Li et al., 2014). These bands confirm the presence of manganese oxide which was derived from spent alkaline battery powder and shows the correct synthesizing procedure of the catalysts. On the other hand, the bands at 1400, 1640, and 3425 cm 1 are attributed to the bending vibration of the H2O and OeH groups in the catalyst (Allahyari et al., 2014; Mohammad Gholipour et al., 2017). In Mn600 catalyst both metal
related and OeH related peaks are intense while in other catalysts only one of these peaks was intense. It was reported in the literature that OeH groups act as adsorbing sites for some volatile organic compounds like toluene and formaldehyde and have an effective role in their oxidation (Magureanu et al., 2011; Zhang et al., 2012). Regarding the FTIR results the 600 C is the proper temperature for the calcination of the manganese oxide catalysts due to the presence of both metal and OeH groups in the FTIR spectrum.

sections.heading: 3.1.2. Catalytic activity
sections.text: Manganese oxide catalysts which were calcined at four different temperatures (400, 500, 600, and 700 C) were tested in a thermal oxidation reactor. Tests were conducted when the reactor temperature was 300 C. As presented in Fig. 4, the highest BTX conversion was achieved in the case of Mn600 catalyst, especially for xylene. The conversions are 98, 96 and 44% for benzene, toluene and xylene, respectively. This result was in good accordance with FTIR analysis results. For VOC oxidation, adsorption of BTX on the catalyst surface is an essential step which is more facile on the surfaces with more hydroxyl groups. On the other hand, more populated Mn2O3 particles can improve the VOC oxidation. Mn600 possessed high accumulated of both hydroxyl and Mn2O3 groups according to FTIR and as a result showed supreme activity in thermal oxidation of BTX.

sections.heading: 3.2. Effect of Manganese Oxide Loading on Alumina
3.2.1. XRD analysis
sections.text: Using XRD, the crystallographic structure of the catalysts was evaluated. XRD patterns of different loadings of manganese on alumina (Mn05Al, Mn10Al, and Mn15Al) with the pure manganese oxide and pure alumina are presented in Fig. 5. The number between the Mn and Al refers to Mn loading percentage on the alumina support. According to JCPDS No. of 00-001-1061, the cubic Mn2O3 is the main phase of the synthesized catalysts. The main peak of Mn2O3 is observed at 2q¼ 33 . The other reflections related to Mn2O3 emerged at 2q¼ 24, 55, and 66 and are in exact accordance with the JCPDS of cubic Mn2O3. In the XRD pattern of the pure Mn2O3, the main peak is very narrow, indicating the high crystalline structure of the Mn2O3 with big crystallite size. In the alumina supported catalysts, the intensity of the manganese oxide peaks differs proportionally to the manganese loading of the catalyst, indicating the correct synthesizing method of the catalysts. It can be noted that alumina related peaks are broad and as a result, the structure of alumina catalyst is amorphous and the size of crystallites is small. According to the literature, amorphous structure of catalyst has a good influence on the removal efficiency of BTX (Abbasi et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 3.2.2. FESEM/EDX analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 6 shows the FESEM images of theMn00Al, Mn05Al, Mn10Al, Mn15Al and Mn600 catalysts. Evaluating the morphologies of the catalysts showed that the surface of the catalysts is made up of the spherical particles. As the Mn loading in the catalysts increases some pores could be seen on the surface of the catalyst. The presence of these pores is beneficial for VOC oxidation as the specific surface extends. These pores exist on both Mn10Al and Mn15Al although in Mn15Al the spherical particles aggregated on the opening of the pores. With the increasing of Mn content in the catalysts, particle agglomeration is occurring which seems that alumina particles are gathering around big cubes of Mn2O3. This may cause the lowering of the specific surface area of the catalyst.
In the case of Mn 600 catalyst, some rods in the nano scale can be seen as well but they disappear in the MnAl catalysts. The fading of these rods is attributed to the good interaction betweenmanganese oxide and alumina in the catalysts The EDX analyse in Fig. 7 indicated that all the materials (Mn, Al, O, and C) which were used in the synthesizing of the catalysts exist on the surface of them. On the other hand, the area of each material peak is proportional with the amount of the material existed in the catalyst. The EDX analysis showed the Mn content in Mn10Al, 9.18wt%; this means the accurate synthesizing procedure of the catalysts. No trace of other impurities can be observed in EDX results which confirm complete
washing of spent battery powder. Good distribution of the materials on the surface of the catalysts causes the strong interaction between the active phase and the support which leads to the high activity of the catalysts (Rahemi et al., 2014).

sections.heading: 3.2.3. BET analysis
sections.text:
The specific surface area of the MnAl catalysts was measured using BET method. All the catalysts had high specific surface area and among themMn00Al had the highest. Fig. 8 shows the specific surface area of the catalysts. It can be noticed that the surface area decreased as the Mn loading in the catalysts increased. The specific
area of the Mn05Al, Mn10Al, and Mn15Al was 122.7, 116.8, and 83.2 (m2/g), respectively. This can be attributed to the accumulation of particles on the surface of the catalyst and blocking the pores of the catalysts as showed in FESEM images.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. TEM/EDX analysis
sections.text:
Fig. 9 presents the TEM and SAED analysis of Mn600. Mn species are in the form of cubes that aggregated on each other. The cubic form of the Mn600 is attributed to the presence of the Mn2O3 species in Mn600 catalyst which is in good accordance with the XRD analysis result. The size of the manganese particles is about 40e70 nm. Miller index of the Mn600 are (2,2,2), (4,0,0), (4,4,0), (4,3,1), and (6,2,2) which were obtained using SAED analysis. The TEM image of Mn10Al is presented in Fig. 10. In this catalyst, the manganese oxide as the active phase is placed on the porous alumina as the support. The porosity of the alumina leads to the
high specific area of the Mn10Al as observed in BET section. Also, it can be seen that alumina is present in the form of Nano rods; this is due to the calcination conditions of the catalyst which by increasing the surface energy in one direction caused the formation of Nano rods. The presence of the diffuse rings in the SAED analysis of Mn10Al shows the amorphous structure of the Mn10Al. Amorphous structure of the catalyst is beneficial towards VOC oxidation. The results of EDX-dot mapping analysis for the Mn600 and Mn10Al catalysts are shown in Fig. 11 and Fig. 12. These results indicated the good dispersion of the manganese oxide in the Mn600 catalyst. For Mn10Al, the EDX dot-mapping results showed the presence of manganese in good interaction with alumina.

sections.heading: 3.2.5. TPR-H2 analysis
sections.text:
The reactivity of the catalyst can be determined using TPR-H2 analysis. The reduction of manganese takes place in few steps as
below (Kim and Shim, 2010; Christel et al., 1997):
MnO2 / Mn2O3 / Mn3O4 / MnO
The TPR-H2 patterns of the Mn600 and Mn10Al are presented in Fig. 13. The first reduction peak of Mn600 catalyst in the 306e434 C is attributed to the reduction of unstable manganese oxide on the surface of the catalyst and during it MnO2 / Mn2O3 occurs. The two peaks in the 440e660 C is attributed to the Mn2O3 /Mn3O4 and Mn3O4 /MnO. The interference of these two peaks shows that these two reduction step occurred simultaneously (Liang et al., 2008). The peak in higher temperatures is attributed to the bulk reduction of the manganese oxide. In other words, the reduction reactions of the manganese oxide start on the surface of
the catalyst and continue until the bulk reactions are done. The TPR-H2 pattern of the Mn10Al catalyst is similar to the Mn600 but in theMn10Al catalyst, the peaks shifted to lower temperatures and some peaks disappeared. Lower temperature reduction means the higher oxygen mobility which is essential in the oxidation reactions. This can be attributed to the good influence of using alumina as the support in the Mn10Al catalyst (Wang et al., 2016).

sections.heading: 3.3. BTX conversion in plasma oxidation and plasma-catalytic oxidation
sections.text:
The conversions for benzene, toluene, and xylene in a plasma oxidation process (without catalyst) are illustrated in Fig. 14 at different voltages. Xylene conversion was low but increased with
increasing the plasma voltage. In 15 kV, xylene conversion achieved 44%, while benzene and toluene regardless of plasma voltage were
oxidized almost completely. This means xylene has a resistant structure and more energetic molecules are needed to break the molecule.
After choosing the 600 C as the proper temperature for calcination, the effect of different manganese oxide loadings on alumina in a plasma catalytic oxidation process was evaluated. As presented in Fig. 15, the Mn10Al catalyst showed the best results toward oxidation of BTX. Increasing manganese oxide loading from 0 to 10% enhanced the xylene conversion from 50.92 to 74% while the conversion decreased to 61.72% in Mn15Al. H2-TPR confirmed Mn2O3 provides the main sites of lattice oxygen (pure Mn2O3 in Man600 has more H2 peak areas compared to Mn10Al which has just 10 % wt. of manganese oxide). Therefore higher activity of Mn10Al in BTX conversion is attributed to higher amount of Mn2O3 and higher amounts of lattice oxygen. Declining BTX conversion in the case of Mn15Al can be interpreted by FESEM and BET analysis which showed the aggregation of the particles on the surface of the Mn15Al catalyst. Another important parameter in the BTX conversion is the nature of pollutants. The lower conversion of xylene is attributed to the presence of two methyl groups attached to the benzene ring which is causing a steric effect which prohibits the
lysis of Mn600 Catalyst.
access of the xylene molecules to the active sites of the catalyst. The higher conversion of toluene towards benzene is attributed to the lower stability of the benzene ring of the toluene. Attached methyl group in the toluene molecule makes the benzene ring less stable which makes the ring opening easier than benzene and this result in the higher conversion of toluene than benzene. Both benzene ring stability and steric effect of the pollutants are in a competition in a plasma catalytic oxidation process. Equilibrium conversion of BTX using Gibbs free energy at room temperature is also presented in Fig. 15. Plasma can produce active species in a manner far from thermodynamic equilibrium (Fridman, 2008). So it can be concluded that the conversion of BTX using plasma is higher than the equilibrium conversion. Comparing BTX conversion in plasma oxidation and plasma-catalytic oxidation shows higher oxidation of xylene in the plasma-catalytic oxidation process. In the plasma oxidation process, oxygen cannot reach to the xylene molecule due to the steric effect of the xylene and it is necessary to immobilize
xylene in a catalyst site to better attack of oxygen.
3.4. Effect of operational and configuration parameters

sections.heading: 3.4.1. Effect of Catalyst Placement in Plasma Reactor
sections.text: The effect of catalyst placement in the plasma reactor using different catalysts in 10 kV was evaluated and results are presented in Fig. 16. In the IPC, catalyst was placed in the plasma region while in the PPC catalyst was placed after the plasma region. Results showed that there is no significant difference between these two types of catalyst placement in the plasma reactor and one of these arrangements can be selected according to the operating conditions like the type of plasma reactor or catalysts (Magureanu et al., 2007).

sections.heading: 3.4.2. Effect of Input Voltage
sections.text:
According to the test and analyses results, the Mn10Al catalyst was chosen as the best catalyst and further evaluations of the
operation parameters was conducted using Mn10Al catalyst. One of the main parameters in plasma-catalytic oxidation is the input voltage. Using the Mn10Al catalyst, the effect of different input voltage was evaluated and the results are illustrated in Fig. 17. Conversion of BTX increased as the input voltage differed from 5 to 15 kV. The production of active species like O and OH radicals is more in higher voltages and this results in higher conversion of BTX but the power consumption of the plasma increases and in the economical viewpoint this is not beneficial (Trinh et al., 2015). As the voltage of the plasma increases, the CO2 selectivity decreases due to the production of unwanted by-products in the process. Catalyst is responsible for elevating the selectivity of the desired products like CO2. Decreasing CO2 selectivity indicated that the residence time of highly energetic compounds in high voltages is so low that immobilization on catalyst sites gets very difficult. Therefore it can be concluded that most of the oxidation might be
happening in gas phase and catalyst has a weak control on the selectivity of products.

sections.heading: 3.4.3. Effect of BTX flow rate
sections.text:
In order to study the effect of BTX flow rate, tests were conducted using the Mn10Al catalyst in 10 kV at four different flow rates (100, 150, 200, and 250ml/min). Flow rate test results are presented in Fig. 18. As the flow rate increases the conversion of BTX decreases as the result of less residence time of pollutants in the plasma reactor and the less probability of collision between the active species and pollutant molecules. Choosing higher flow rate in a plasma-catalytic oxidation process can be considered as the higher nominal capacity of the process, so it was concluded that the 200ml/min is the highest flow rate toward BTX oxidation with no
drop in the conversions of BTX.

sections.heading: 3.4.4. Effect of catalyst loading in plasma-catalytic oxidation
sections.text: Fig. 19 presented the effect of different catalyst loadings along the respective GC graph of each one. Choosing the proper amount for the catalyst loading is related to the kinetic considerations and parameters like the reactor volume and flow rate; considering these parameters, three different loadings of catalyst (0.1, 0.2, and 0.3 g) were chosen in this research. As the catalyst loading exceeds, the conversion of BTX increases as well. This can be attributed to the increase in active sites of catalyst in the oxidation process and more possibility of interaction between the pollutants with the active sites. On the other hand, using an extra amount of catalyst in the process can cause the pressure to drop in the reactor. Concerning the mentioned points and obtained results, using 0.2 g of catalyst showed the best results and was chosen as the proper catalyst loading in this research.

sections.heading: 3.5. Mechanism of BTX oxidation
sections.text:
BTX oxidation in this research can be studied in two forms; first, using plasma without catalyst and the other one is using plasma with the catalyst. In the first case, the oxidation process happens by the production of high energy electrons, hydroxyl radicals, and active species of nitrogen and oxygen. The interaction between the pollutant molecules and high energy electrons, make the pollutant molecules excited. Afterwards, these excited molecules react with the active species and eventually turn to H2O and CO2 as the oxidation products. This mechanism is illustrated in Fig. 20.
In the case of using plasmawith the catalyst, the same reactions happen as well as the additional reaction on the surface of the catalyst. Excited pollutant molecules and the active species adsorb on the surface of the catalyst and react to do the oxidation process. Using manganese oxide catalyst, several parameters affect the surface reaction like the adsorption of the molecules on the catalyst surface, the chemical bonds of MneO, the number of species adsorbed on the surface, and the conversion of Mn2O3, Mn3O4, and MnO. In the plasma-catalytic oxidation process O3, O2, and the high energy electrons can be adsorbed on the catalyst surface and make the conversions of Mn4þ, Mn3þ and Mn2þ possible, that way the BTX oxidation occurs. Themechanism of BTX oxidation in a plasmacatalytic oxidation process is presented in Fig. 21.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Manganese oxide as the active phase was synthesized by a hydrometallurgical method from the spent alkaline battery powder and was impregnated on alumina as the support with different loadings. Among the 5, 10, and 15% loadings of manganese oxide on alumina,10% showed the best results due to bettermorphology and higher specific surface area. After choosing Mn10Al catalyst, different parameters were evaluated in order to get the highest BTX conversion. The results showed that best condition is 10 kV with 0.2 g of Mn10Al catalyst as the 200ml/min of pollutant flow enters the plasma reactor. Using these conditions, the conversion reached its highest values of 97, 99, and 74% for the benzene, toluene, and xylene, respectively. metadata.abstractText: In this paper, the powder of manganese oxide was recovered from spent alkaline batteries and the effect of calcination temperature on the physiochemical properties of resultant powder was studied. Synthesized manganese oxide was impregnated at different percentages on alumina and the resultant material was used as catalyst for oxidation of benzene, toluene, and xylene (BTX) in a hybrid plasma-catalytic process. Manganese oxide/alumina (MnAl) catalysts were analyzed by FTIR, XRD, FESEM, EDX, BET, TEM, and TPR-H2 and the results indicated that high crystalline big cubes of manganese oxide are in good connection with highly dispersed ultra-fine nanoparticles of alumina. Enhancing the Mn content increased the agglomeration of alumina particles probably around the cubes of manganese oxide. Nitrogen adsorption measurements (BET) showed that the specific surface area of these catalysts was high but reduced with increasing Mn percent. TPR-H2 showed that using alumina had a good impact on the redox ability of the catalyst. Oxidation of BTX using synthesized MnAl catalysts was carried out in the presence of plasma. While MnAl catalysts showed similar results in benzene and toluene oxidation percent (97e98%), the oxidation of xylene was difficult and depended on the Mn percent so that the catalyst with 10% wt. of manganese oxide indicated 74% of xylene oxidation while higher or lower Mn contents exhibited lower oxidation percent. In order to evaluate the experimental parameters, the influence of plasma input voltage, catalyst location in the plasma reactor, BTX flow rate, and the catalyst loadings were investigated. Results showed that benzene and toluene were oxidized almost completely regardless of input plasma voltage but the amount of xylene oxidation soared with increasing the voltage. Moreover, the catalyst location in the reactor had no significant influence on the conversion of BTX whereas increasing the flow rate led to a decline in BTX removal efficiency. © 2019 Elsevier Ltd.
